conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their positions as functions of time by finding the area under the velocity-time graph.
The area under the curve represents the displacement of an object over time.
For Object A: From t = 0 to t = t1, the area under the curve is negative. From t = t1 to t = t2, the area is positive.
For Object B: From t = 0 to t = t2, the area under the curve is positive.
Express the position of Object A as a function of time using the integral of its velocity.
Position of Object A is negative for 0 ≤ t < t1 and positive for t1 ≤ t ≤ t2.
Express the position of Object B as a function of time using the integral of its velocity.
Position of Object B is negative for 0 ≤ t < t2 and positive for t2 ≤ t.
Calculate the difference in positions |s_A(t) - s_B(t)| to find when objects are farthest apart.
For 0 ≤ t < t1, s_A(t) - s_B(t) is positive.
For t1 ≤ t < t2, s_A(t) - s_B(t) is positive.
For t ≥ t2, s_A(t) - s_B(t) is negative.
Maximum difference occurs before t1 as objects move in the same direction after t1.
The two objects are farthest apart at t = t1.
